A minimum allocation for smaller coastal states "will protect struggling small fishing operations that might be underserved if funding is distributed in proportion to the value of commercial fisheries in each state without instituting a minimum allocation," the senators wrote.

Without a minimum allocation, larger operations may receive a disproportionate amount of available funds, leaving struggling small businesses in states like Delaware and Connecticut with little help‚Äîand little recourse.

The #CARESAct appropriated $300 million to @NOAA for fishery disaster assistance. However, NOAA and OMB are still considering how to distribute these funds among impacted fishing states.

These senators are urging NOAA to consider a minimum allocation for smaller coastal states.

COVID-19 has devastated fisheries, as domestic purchasing has plunged and exports have slowed.

With limited capital, fishing communities‚Äîbusiness owners, crews and processing plant workers‚Äîare facing financial hardships that put their livelihoods at risk.

Michiganders are doing just that every day, so I was disappointed to see that many of those protesting today took the opposite approach, putting their own interests ahead of the health and safety of their fellow citizens.

Just as our parents and grandparents were called to serve & endure, we are now called to serve & endure. As they rose to the challenges of their era, so shall we.

And they did that by realizing that in a community we all have responsibilities to each other, esp. during a crisis.

They are trying to figure out when we can work again and where, how to save our businesses, and how to pay bills without a paycheck.

But the majority of Michiganders also realize that our country is going through a once-in-a-generation crisis.

But we also have the right to speak out against that behavior, and honor the vast majority of our fellow citizens who choose a different path.

The majority of Michiganders are suffering significant loss of income and profound changes to their everyday lives.

The right to free speech is so fundamental that the protesters today were able to exercise their rights at the expense of the health of the police, sergeant at arms officers, staff and elected leaders who they yelled at, at close range, without face masks.
Michiganders can even brandish semi-automatic weapons inside our State Capitol and hurl insults, despite the inherent threat those actions can pose.

Americans have the right to carry signs with hateful slogans and swastikas, to wave confederate flags, and to transform what could have been a protest about public health restrictions into a rally that promoted violence and hate, as many did today.

In response to the few hundred protestors who showed up in our Capitol and my district today:
